body.p: To determine the relative effectiveness of different study strategies for the SAT, suppose three groups of students are randomly selected: One group took the SAT without any prior studying; the second group took the SAT after studying on their own from a common study booklet available in the bookstore; and the third group took the SAT after completing a paid summer study session from a private test-prep company.

The means and standard deviations of the resulting SAT scores from this hypothetical study are summarized below: Since we are comparing more than 2 groups, we will use ANOVA to test whether the data provide evidence that SAT score is related to study strategy.
Ha: μ1, μ2, and μ3 are not all equal
The analysis was run on the data and the following output was obtained:
Which of the following is a valid conclusion based on the output? Check all that apply.

input.choice: The data provide strong evidence that SAT scores are related to learning strategy.

The data provide strong evidence that SAT scores are related to learning strategy in the following way: The mean SAT score for students who pay for coaching is higher than the mean SAT score for students who study themselves, which in turn is higher than that of students who do not study for the test.
The data provide strong evidence that the three mean SAT scores (representing the three learning strategies) are not all equal.
The data do not provide sufficient evidence that SAT scores are related to learning strategy.

response.feedback: Incorrect. You are correct that “The data provide strong evidence that SAT scores are related to learning strategy” is a valid conclusion. Since the p-value is essentially 0, we have strong evidence to reject H0 and in favor of the alternative. However, there is at least one other valid conclusion.

Incorrect. “The data provide strong evidence that SAT scores are related to learning strategy in the following way: The mean SAT score for students who pay for coaching is higher than the mean SAT score for students who study themselves, which in turn is higher than that of students who do not study for the test” is not a valid conclusion. Although ANOVA can tell you whether or not all of the means are equal, it cannot tell you how they are ordered (it cannot tell you which way of preparing for the SAT works best). Also, there is at least one valid conclusion.

Incorrect. You are correct that “The data provide strong evidence that the three mean SAT scores (representing the three learning strategies) are not all equal” is a valid conclusion. The alternative hypothesis claims that the three SAT means (of the three learning strategies) are not all equal. However, there is at least one other valid conclusion.

Incorrect. “The data do not provide sufficient evidence that SAT scores are related to learning strategy” is not a valid conclusion. The p-value is extremely small (approximately 0), therefore strong evidence exists to reject H0. Also, there is at least one valid conclusion.

Incorrect. You are correct that “The data provide strong evidence that SAT scores are related to learning strategy” is a valid conclusion. Since the p-value is essentially 0, we have strong evidence to reject H0 and in favor of the alternative. However, “The data provide strong evidence that SAT scores are related to learning strategy in the following way: The mean SAT score for students who pay for coaching is higher than the mean SAT score for students who study themselves, which in turn is higher than that of students who do not study for the test” is not a valid conclusion. Although ANOVA can tell you whether or not all of the means are equal, it cannot tell you how they are ordered (it cannot tell you which way of preparing for the SAT works best). Also, there is at least one other valid conclusion.

Correct. “The data provide strong evidence that SAT scores are related to learning strategy” and “The data provide strong evidence that the three mean SAT scores (representing the three learning strategies) are not all equal” both are valid conclusions. Since the p-value is essentially 0, we have strong evidence to reject H0 and in favor of the alternative. The alternative hypothesis claims that the three SAT means (of the three learning strategies) are not all equal. In other words, we have strong evidence that performance on the SATs is related to learning strategy.

Incorrect. You are correct that “The data provide strong evidence that SAT scores are related to learning strategy” is a valid conclusion. Since the p-value is essentially 0, we have strong evidence to reject H0 and in favor of the alternative. However, “The data do not provide sufficient evidence that SAT scores are related to learning strategy” is not a valid conclusion. The p-value is extremely small (approximately 0), therefore strong evidence exists to reject H0. Also, there is at least one other valid conclusion.

Although ANOVA can tell you whether or not all of the means are equal, it cannot tell you how they are ordered (it cannot tell you which way of preparing for the SAT works best). Also, “The data do not provide sufficient evidence that SAT scores are related to learning strategy” is not a valid conclusion. Incorrect. There is at least one valid conclusion.

body.p: Using four methods to teach ANOVA, do these four samples differ enough from each other to reject the null hypothesis that type of instruction has no effect on mean test performance?
Since we are comparing more than 2 groups, we will use ANOVA to test whether the data provide evidence that SAT score is related to study strategy.
Ha: µ1, µ2, µ3, µ4 are not all equal
The analysis was run on the data and the following output was obtained:
Which of the following is a valid conclusion based on this output?

input.choice: The data provide strong evidence that the four mean scores (representing the four teaching strategies) are not all equal.
The data do not provide sufficient evidence that scores are related to teaching strategy.

response.feedback: Correct. “The data provide strong evidence that the four mean scores (representing the four teaching strategies) are not all equal" is a valid conclusion. Since the p-value is essentially 0, we have strong evidence to reject H0 and in favor of the alternative. The alternative hypothesis claims that the four means (of the four teaching strategies) are not all equal. In other words, we have strong evidence that performance is related to teaching strategy. Although ANOVA can tell you whether or not all of the means are equal, it cannot tell you how they are ordered (it cannot tell you which way of teaching works best).

Incorrect. “The data do not provide sufficient evidence that scores are related to learning teaching strategy" is not a valid conclusion. The p-value is extremely small (approximately 0), therefore strong evidence exists to reject H0 and favor of the alternative. The alternative hypothesis claims that the four means (of the four teaching strategies) are not all equal. In other words, we have strong evidence that performance is related to teaching strategy.
